translated: Composed by Vasubandhu
Translated by Tripiá¹­aka Master ParamÄrtha of India during the Chen Dynasty
The wisdom of all modes extinguishes all darkness, pulling sentient beings out of the mud of birth and death,
I bow my head to the great teacher's teachings in accordance with truth, and will explain the Abhidharma-koÅ›a.
The commentary says:

If a person wishes to compose a treatise correctly, they should make others understand the unique qualities of the great teacher, thus praising his virtues first, and then bowing their head to the great teacher.
This verse only refers to the World-Honored Buddha.
The verse says:
The wisdom of all modes extinguishes all darkness.
The commentary says:
All darkness is extinguished by the wisdom of all modes.
Ignorance about all dharmas obstructs the seeing of the true meaning, and is therefore called darkness.

This ignorance is completely extinguished in the World-Honored Buddha, because the ultimate antidote has been attained. It is permanently extinguished in all dharmas of all modes, and does not arise again, and is therefore called extinguished.
Pratyekabuddhas and Å›rÄvakas, although they have removed ignorance regarding all dharmas, due to the extreme non-arising of defiled ignorance, not by all kinds.
Why is this?
The other noble ones have defiled ignorance regarding the TathÄgata's unique dharmas and other objects, for the longest time, in limitless places and distinctions.
This shows the perfection of one's own benefit.
Having praised the Buddha, next he praises the World-Honored One with the perfection of benefiting others.
The verse says:
Pulling sentient beings out of the mud of birth and death.
The explanation says:
Birth and death is the place where the world sinks and is difficult to cross, so it is likened to mud.

Sentient beings sink in it without anyone to rescue them. Only the World-Honored Buddha, wishing to compassionately deliver them, extends the hand of the correct teaching and reasonably rescues these people, being in accord with the practice of benefiting oneself and others.
The verse says:
Bowing to the Great Teacher's teachings in accordance with truth.
The explanation says:
Bowing one's head to the feet is called prostrating.
The establishment of the teaching is not empty, and is called the Great Master.
Upright is called according to principle.
Obtaining goodness and leaving evil is called teaching.
Expounding this teaching according to principle is a skillful means for benefiting others.
By means of the teaching according to principle, one rescues sentient beings from the mud of birth and death, not by means of spiritual powers, grace, virtue, and so forth.
Having prostrated to the teacher who teaches according to principle, what is one to do?
The verse states:
I shall explain the Abhidharma-koÅ›a.
The commentary states:
This Dharma is generally called the teaching of liberation.
What is its specific name?
Abhidharma-koÅ›a.
What is the Dharma called Abhidharma?
The verse states:
Pure wisdom and its auxiliaries are called Abhidharma.
The commentary states:
Wisdom refers to discernment of dharmas. Purity means being undefiled, i.e., uncontaminated wisdom. Auxiliaries refer to the causes and conditions that support it.
If that is so, then the uncontaminated five aggregates are called Abhidharma, which is the true Abhidharma.
If it is said that the nominal Abhidharma is:
The verse says:
The treatises that can attain this Dharma.
The explanation says:

It is the contaminated wisdom of contemplation, the contaminated wisdom of hearing, the wisdom of birth and attainment, and the treatises that accompany it. It is said that it can transmit and produce uncontaminated wisdom, because it is the provision for uncontaminated wisdom, and it is also called Abhidharma.
For what meaning is this name established?
Because it can uphold its own characteristics, it is called Dharma.
Or the characteristic of nirvana, which is the true Dharma among all dharmas, is called Dharma.
Because this wisdom is opposed to all dharmas and manifests in the Dharma, it is called Abhidharma.
How is this treatise called AbhidharmakoÅ›a?
The verse says:
Because the meaning corresponds to the Abhidharma and enters this collection.
The explanation says:
Those phrases are called Abhidharma, because they correspond to the supreme meaning and enter this treatise. Therefore, this treatise is called a treasury with regard to it.
Furthermore, the verse says:
The treatise relies on the Abhidharma and is called KoÅ›a.
The commentary explains:
Abhidharma is the basis of this treatise.
Why is it so?
Because this treatise is produced from that Dharma.
That [Abhidharma] also receives the name of piá¹­aka in this treatise. For this reason, this treatise is called AbhidharmakoÅ›a.
Furthermore, what is the function of this Dharma?
What person first expounded this Dharma, and why does the teacher respectfully wish to explain it?
A verse says:

Apart from the discernment of dharmas, there is no other means to pacify the afflictions. The world revolves in the ocean of existence due to the afflictions. For this reason, the Buddha transmitted the Abhidharma.
The commentary explains:

Apart from the factor of awakening that is the discernment of dharmas, there are no other means to eliminate the afflictions. The afflictions cause the world to revolve in saá¹ƒsÄra, in the ocean of birth and death.
For this right reason, in order to enable disciples to discern the dharmas, the Great Teacher, the World-Honored Buddha, first expounded the Abhidharma.
If one departs from this correct teaching, disciples are unable to discern the true Dharma in accordance with reason.
The World-Honored Buddha scattered and taught this Dharma everywhere, and the disciples such as the Venerable KÄtyÄyanÄ«putra compiled and arranged it.
It is like the Venerable DharmatrÄta compiling and arranging the UdÄna and GÄthÄ categories. The VibhÄá¹£Ä masters have transmitted this saying.
What are the dharmas that are to be discerned?
In order to enable others to discern those dharmas, the World-Honored Buddha taught the Abhidharma.
Verse:
Contaminated and uncontaminated dharmas.
Explanation:
In brief, all dharmas are said to be either contaminated or uncontaminated.
What are the contaminated ones among them?
Verse:
The conditioned, excluding the noble path, are contaminated.
Explanation:
Except for the truth of the path, the remaining conditioned dharmas are said to be contaminated.
Why is it so?
Verse:
In them, the contaminants increase through following and lying in wait.
Explanation:

If there were such a meaning, the outflows would arise with the two truths of cessation and path as their objects, and they would not sleep in them because they do not increase. Therefore, it is not possible to establish the existence of outflows in them.
The meaning of not sleeping is for the purpose of countering objections, and will be explained in detail later in the chapter on discriminating afflictions.
Having explained the dharmas with outflows, what are the dharmas without outflows?
The verse states:
The noble path and the three kinds of unconditioned are dharmas without outflows.
The commentary states:
What are the three unconditioned?
The verse states:
Space and the two cessations.
The commentary states:
What are the two cessations?
Cessation through discernment and cessation not through discernment.
Thus, the three unconditioned such as space and the noble path are said to be dharmas without outflows.
Why is this?
Because the outflows cannot sleep in them, it is explained in brief.
Among the three unconditioned, what is space?
The verse states:
Here, space is unobstructed.
The commentary states:
Space has the nature of being unobstructed and unimpeded, therefore form can move within it.
Verse:
Extinction through discernment is called permanent separation.
Explanation:
Permanently separated from defiled dharmas is called extinction through discernment.
Discerning each of the noble truths such as suffering is called discernment, which is the superior cause of wisdom.
The benefit obtained through this is called extinction through discernment.

It should be fully said to be the extinction obtained through discernment, but because it is spoken concisely it is simply called extinction through discernment, like a cart yoked to oxen is called an ox cart.
Is extinction through discernment one for all defiled dharmas, or is it not one?
It is not one.
How is it?
Verse:
Each corresponds to the various bonds.
Explanation:
The quantity of extinction through discernment is the same as the quantity of the bonds.

If it were not so, then by realizing the extinction through discernment of the delusions eliminated by seeing suffering, one would have to realize at the same time the extinction through discernment of all the delusions. If that were so, then cultivating the other antidotal paths would be empty and without result.
The Buddha's scriptures say:
Cessation through discrimination has no similar class.
What is the meaning of this statement?
Cessation through discrimination has no similar cause, nor is it the similar cause of others.
This is the meaning of the sutra, not that there is nothing similar to it.
Having explained cessation through discrimination,
The verse states:
Constantly preventing the arising of desire, there is a separate non-analytical cessation.
The explanation states:

The ability to permanently prevent the arising of future dharmas, different from cessation through discrimination, is called non-analytical cessation, because it is not attained through discrimination.
How is it attained?
Because the conditions are incomplete.

For example, when a person's mental consciousness and eye faculty take a single visible form as an object, at that time the other visible forms, sounds, smells, tastes, and tactile objects that have just ceased cannot be taken as objects by the five consciousnesses to give rise to further cognition.
Why is this?

Because the five consciousnesses do not have the ability to take past sense objects as their objects. Therefore, consciousness and so forth have non-analytical cessation, because the conditions are incomplete.
The four alternatives can be established based on the two cessations.
There are dharmas that only have pratisamkhyÄnirodha, namely past and present dharmas that will definitely arise and are with outflows.
There are dharmas that only have apratisamkhyÄnirodha, namely dharmas that will not arise and are without outflows and conditioned.
There are dharmas that have both kinds of cessation, namely conditioned dharmas that will not arise and are with outflows.
There are dharmas that have neither kind of cessation, namely past and present dharmas that will definitely arise and are without outflows.
The three unconditioned dharmas have been explained.
Previously it was said that conditioned dharmas, excluding the noble path, are called with outflows.
What are the conditioned dharmas?
The verse states:
Moreover, all conditioned dharmas are called the five aggregates such as form.
The commentary explains:

The aggregate of form, the aggregate of feeling, the aggregate of perception, the aggregate of mental formations, and the aggregate of consciousness - these five aggregates encompass all conditioned dharmas.
They are called conditioned because they are brought about by causes and conditions that have arrived and accumulated.
Why is it so?
Because there is no dharma that arises without conditions or with only one condition, and because they belong to that category.
There is no obstruction in the future, like a solitary hut.
Verse:
The path of the world is said to depend on existence, separation, and continuity.
Explanation:
These conditioned dharmas, having already, presently, and about to be practiced, are called the path of the world.
Moreover, because they are consumed by impermanence.
Speech refers to spoken language.
The meaning that corresponds to this speech is called the basis of speech, because it is the speech that grasps the meaning.
The Buddha's sutras say that conditioned dharmas are called the basis of speech.
If it were not so, then it would contradict the Abhidharma-samuccaya.
That treatise says:
The basis of speech is included in the eighteen elements. Eternal separation is called liberation, which refers to nirvana.
Because all conditioned dharmas are eternally separated from nirvana.
Conditioned dharmas have separation, while nirvana has no separation.
Conditioned dharmas are called having separation, and because they have causes they are called having continuity.
Continuity has the meaning of cause.
The VaibhÄá¹£ika masters make this statement:
Such are the different names for conditioned dharmas.
Furthermore, these conditioned dharmas,
The contaminated are called the appropriated aggregates.
What is shown by this?
Those that are appropriated can be said to be the appropriated aggregates.

But the aggregates that are not appropriated are the uncontaminated conditioned dharmas. Here, the afflictions are the appropriator, and the aggregates are born from the appropriator, so they are called the appropriated aggregates, like grass, trees, chaff, and fire.
Furthermore, because they follow the appropriator, like the king's men.
Furthermore, because the appropriators arise from them, they are called the appropriated aggregates, like flower trees and fruit trees.
These contaminated dharmas,
Are also said to have disputes.
What is shown by this?
The afflictions are called disputes, because they can disturb wholesome dharmas and harm oneself and others.
Therefore, because they are followed by disputes, they are said to have disputes.
Like the contaminated.
Furthermore, a verse says:
The truths of suffering and accumulation are worldly.
What is shown by this?
Because they go against the intention of the noble ones, they are called suffering.
Because suffering arises from various views, it is called accumulation.
Because it is destroyed, it is called the world, because it has an antidote.
Verse:
The realm of views and the three existences.
Explanation:
Because it abides in the basis of various views, following and increasing, it is the realm of views.
It is called existence because it only causes existence.
Thus, the meaning of defiled dharmas is explained. The specific names have already been explained before.
The five aggregates such as form, in this regard, a verse says:
The form aggregate is the five sense faculties, the five sense objects, and non-information.
Explanation:
The five sense faculties are the eye, ear, nose, tongue, and body;
The five sense objects are the objects of the five sense faculties such as the eye, namely form, sound, smell, taste, and touch;
And non-information, this much is called the form aggregate.
In this regard, these are the previously mentioned five sense objects such as form. A verse says:
This pure form that is the basis of consciousness is called the sense faculties such as the eye.
Explanation:
The five kinds of pure form that are the bases of the consciousnesses of form, sound, smell, taste, and touch should be known in order as the eye, ear, nose, tongue, and body faculties.
As the World-Honored Buddha said:
Bhiká¹£us!
The eye is an internal sense base, composed of the four great elements, and is of the nature of pure form. And so on, it is explained in detail.
Moreover, the five faculties such as the eye have already been explained. The pure form that is the basis of this consciousness is called the eye faculty, etc.
The meaning of the basis of the consciousnesses of the eye faculty, etc. is like this.
If this meaning is established, then it accords with the Abhidharma-samuccaya.
That treatise says:
What is the eye faculty?
It is the pure form that is the basis of eye consciousness.
Having explained the five faculties, next we should explain the five objects.
Regarding this, a verse says:
Form is twofold.
The commentary says:
One is manifest form, and the other is shape.
Manifest form is of four kinds, namely blue, yellow, red, and white. The other colors are not different from these four colors.
Are the eight shapes such as long, etc.
The visible form sense base is again said to beğŸ”½Twenty.
That is,
blue, yellow, red, white, long, short, square, round, high, low, even, uneven, clouds, smoke, dust, mist, shadow, light, radiance, and darkness.
Some say
that space is a single color, so there are twenty-one colors.
Among them, even shape is called even.
Uneven is called uneven.
Earth vapor is called mist.
Sun rays are called light.
Moon, stars, fire, medicine, jewels, and lightning rays are called radiance.
Among them, if a color appears, it is called shadow, and the opposite is called darkness.
The other colors are easy to understand, so they are not explained now.
There is a visible form sense base that is apparent but not shaped, namely blue, yellow, red, white, shadow, light, radiance, and darkness.
There is a form sense base that has shape but not manifestation, namely, the part of the form sense base that has length, etc., which is characterized by the bodily intimation.
There is a form sense base that has both manifestation and shape, namely, the remaining forms.
Other masters say:
There is a form sense base that has neither shape nor manifestation, namely, non-revealing form.
Other masters say:
Only light and radiance have manifestation but not shape.
Why is this?
Because we always see that various forms such as blue, etc., have distinctions of length, etc.
How can one thing be the object of two cognitions?
Because these two forms appear in one dust.
This is not so.
Because it would be a counter-question regarding the bodily intimation.
Having explained the form sense base,
the verse states:
The sound sense base is of eight kinds.
The explanation states:

It has as its cause the four great elements that are either appropriated or not appropriated, and it has the names of sentient beings or the names of non-sentient beings. These are called the four sounds.
This sound becomes eight kinds due to the distinctions of being pleasant or unpleasant.
Among these, that which has the clinging-aggregate as its cause refers to sounds such as speech, clapping, etc.
That which does not have the clinging-aggregate as its cause refers to sounds such as wind, trees, waves, etc.
That which is the name of a sentient being refers to sounds with meaning, different from this is not the name of a sentient being.
Other masters say:
There is another kind of sound that has both clinging-aggregates and non-clinging-aggregates as its cause, namely that produced by the combination of hands and drums.
Just as one visible form atom is not allowed to arise from two great elements, this sound should also be so.
Having discussed sound,
the verse states:
There are six tastes.
The commentary explains:
They are distinguished by sweetness, sourness, saltiness, spiciness, bitterness, and blandness.
The verse states:
There are four smells.
The commentary explains:
They are distinguished by fragrance, foul smell, equality, and inequality.
In the Abhidharma, smell is said to be of three kinds: fragrance, foul smell, and equality.
The verse states:
The tangible objects are of eleven kinds.
The commentary explains:
It should be known that there are eleven kinds of tangibility, namely the four great elements, smoothness, roughness, heaviness, lightness, cold, hunger, and thirst.
Among them, the four great elements will be explained later.
Softness is called smoothness.
Roughness is called roughness.
That which can be weighed is called heavy, and the opposite is lightness.
Desire for heat is called cold.ğŸ”½Desire for food is called hunger.
Desire for drink is called thirst.
The name of the result is established for the cause, therefore it is said like this.
As it is said in the Buddha's GÄthÄ:
The Buddhas' birth is blissful, the teaching of the true Dharma is also blissful,
The bliss of the great assembly's harmony, the bliss of gathering and going forth.
In the form realm, there is no tangibility of hunger or thirst, but there are other tangibilities.
Among them, if their clothes cannot be weighed individually, they are also measurable because they are created by the aggregation of the four great elements.
There is no cold tangibility that can harm them, but there is cold tangibility that can benefit them.
Others explain it like this.
It has already been said that form has many kinds. Sometimes the eye consciousness arises from one thing, when at that time it distinguishes one kind.
Sometimes the eye consciousness arises from many things, when at that time there is nothing to distinguish.
It is like a military crowd with innumerable forms and colors, and seeing many jewels from afar should be understood in the same way.
The ear consciousness and so on are also like this.
If the body consciousness is at most, it arises from five contacts, namely the four great elements and contact.
Among the contacts, smoothness and so on are one, according to some teachers' doctrines.
There are also other teachers who say:
The body consciousness arises from all eleven contacts.
If that is so, then the object is grasped as a whole.

The common object becomes the object of the five consciousnesses, and the five consciousnesses should not only have specific objects, because they take the specific characteristics of the sense bases as their objects.
If it is accepted that they have specific characteristics as their objects, but not the specific characteristics of the objects, what is wrong with that?
This meaning should be considered.
If both the body and tongue sense faculties encounter their objects simultaneously, which consciousness arises first?
The consciousness that arises depends on the strength of the object.
If the objects are equal,
the tongue consciousness arises first.
Because the continuity is attracted by the desire for food.
Thus the five faculties, five objects, and the way of apprehending objects have been explained.
Now we will explain non-informative form.
Verse:
In a distracted mind or mindless state, flowing along with purity or impurity, relying on the four great elements, what is non-informative form said to be?
Explanation:

Distracted mind refers to a different object. Entering the attainment of non-perception and the attainment of cessation of perception and feeling is called mindless, to indicate it is not a distracted mind or a mind with perception, it says or.
This is a semblance of continuity, either simultaneous or subsequent, so it is called flowing along.
Wholesome is called pure, unwholesome is called impure, and the attainment of continuity is also like this.
To distinguish this from that, it says relying on the four great elements.
The VaibhÄá¹£ika masters say:
Relying means cause.
The four great elements are non-indicative, because they are the five causes of arising, etc.
In order to show the reason for establishing the name, it says what.
Although this dharma has form and action as its nature, unlike indicative form it cannot cause others to know, and is therefore called non-indicative.
In order to show that this is the explanation of other masters, it says it is said.
If it is explained briefly, indicative form and the good and evil form produced by samÄdhi are called non-indicative.
It was previously said to be based on the four great elements. What are the four great elements?
The verse says:
The great elements refer to the earth element, and the water, fire, and wind elements.
The commentary says:
These four great elements are able to uphold their own characteristics and derivative form, and are therefore called elements.
Why are the four elements called great?
Because all other forms rely on them and they form the gross, they are called great.
Moreover, because they arise pervasively and completely, and their shape and quantity are great within the aggregates of earth, water, fire, and wind.
Furthermore, it is called great because it can increase and expand the production of all material things and can accomplish great deeds in the world.
Next, in what activities are the elements of earth, etc. established?
What are their intrinsic natures?
A verse says:
They are established in the activities of supporting, etc.
The commentary says:

In the four activities of excellent support, cohesion, ripening, and expansion, the elements of earth, water, fire, and wind are established in order. Expansion means increasing and benefiting, causing the continuity of the great elements to arise in different places, like blowing on a lamp flame. This is called the activity of the four great elements. As for their intrinsic natures, in order:
A verse says:
Their natures are solidity, fluidity, heat, and motion.
The commentary says:
The earth element has solidity as its nature, the water element has fluidity as its nature, the fire element has heat as its nature, and the wind element has motion as its nature.
It causes the continuity of the great elements to arise in different places, like blowing on a lamp flame, and is called motion.
The Treatise on Distinguishing the Meanings says:
What is the wind element?
It is called light touch.
The scriptures also say the same. Sometimes it is said that light touch is the derivative form. This dharma takes movement as its fixed nature, so movement is said to be the wind element.
It is precisely by revealing its function that the self-nature of wind is shown.
Next, what is the difference between earth, etc., and the earth element, etc.?
The verse says:
Earth is said to be the visible form of shape and color, established by worldly names and concepts;
Water and fire are also the same.
The commentary says:
When worldly people manifest the earth element to others, they only manifest visible form and shape.
Just as they manifest the earth element, so they manifest the water and fire elements.
They only manifest visible form and shape. Therefore, based on worldly provisional names and concepts, the form sense base is said to be the three great elements such as earth, etc.
The verse says:
Only the wind element.
The commentary says:
This wind element is said to be wind by worldly people.
The verse says:
It is also the same.
The commentary says:
Just as worldly people provisionally speak of visible form and shape as earth, so they also speak of wind, sometimes saying black wind or round wind.
How can you say that non-information is the last aggregate, called form?
Because it is manifested and subject to change.
The Buddha, the World-Honored One, said:
Monks!
Because this dharma changes and is subject to change, it is called the form aggregate.
What dharma can change?
Because it changes due to contact with hands and other things, as explained in the sutras.
Because it has resistance, it can change.
Moreover, in the meaning-based sutras it is said:
People who seek sensual pleasures, tainted and attached by the thirst for love,
If their desires are not fulfilled, they are as if pierced by a thorn.
Moreover, another teacher says:
This form arises from change in the desire realm, and because it has resistance, it is called form.
If so, the ultimate particle of form should not be form, because it cannot be changed or destroyed.
This statement is not a criticism.
The ultimate particle of form does not exist alone, because it does not combine;
If it exists in combination, then it can be changed and destroyed.

If this is so, past and future form should not be form, because they have already been destroyed or will be destroyed, and because their nature is that of being destroyed, like fuel that is being burned.

If this is so, non-informative form should not be form, because it is destroyed when the form that informs is destroyed, and because it is destroyed in the same way as that form, like a shadow is destroyed when the tree is destroyed.
This is not so, because non-informative form is not destroyed.
If this is so, when the form that informs ceases, non-informative form should also cease, just as a shadow ceases when the tree ceases.
There is another opinion:
Non-informative form is also destroyed because its basis is destroyed.
This is not so.
If this is so, eye consciousness and so on should also be form, because they are destroyed when their basis is destroyed.
Therefore your assertion is not reasonable.
Nevertheless, there is a difference.
Why is this?
Non-informative form arises based on the four great elements, like a shadow arises based on a tree, or light arises based on a jewel.

The eye consciousness and so forth are not like this. They arise in dependence on the eye faculty and so forth. The faculties are only the causes for the arising of the eye consciousness and so forth.
This doctrine is not the VaibhÄá¹£ika doctrine, namely that the shadow arises in dependence on the tree and the light arises in dependence on the jewel.
That teacher says:
The atoms of the manifest form of shadows and so forth each depend on their own four great elements.
If it is really like this, then the shadow and light arise in dependence on the tree and jewel, and the non-informative should not be the same in dependence.
Why is this?
The four great elements that are the basis of the non-informative have already ceased.
That teacher does not allow the non-informative to cease accordingly. Therefore this doctrine is not a successful defense.
There is another teacher who establishes a separate defense, saying:

The eye consciousness and so forth have different bases of dependence. Some have a basis of dependence that is subject to change and decay, like the eye and so forth. Some have a basis of dependence that is not subject to change and decay, like the mental consciousness and so forth.

The basis of dependence of the non-informative is not like this. Therefore this objection is not equal. Therefore this doctrine should be so, because it is subject to change and decay, it is called the form aggregate.
This dharma has already been explained as having the nature of the form aggregate.
Verse:
These faculties and objects are further explained as the ten entrances and the ten realms.
Explanation:
If established from the perspective of entrances, there are eighteen, namely the eye entrance, form entrance, up to the body entrance and tactile object entrance.
If established from the perspective of realms, there are ten realms, namely the eye realm, form realm, up to the body realm and tactile object realm.
Having explained the form aggregate and the establishment of entrances and realms, next we should explain the aggregates of feeling, etc.
Regarding this, a verse says:
The aggregate of feeling is the experience of contact.
Explanation:
There are three kinds of experiences of contact called the aggregate of feeling.
What are the three?
They are the ability to experience pleasant, painful, and neither-pleasant-nor-painful contacts, which are called the three feelings.
Furthermore, if these feelings are distinguished, they become the six collections of feelings, namely feelings born from eye contact up to feelings born from mind contact.
A verse says:
The aggregate of conception is the grasping of characteristics.
Explanation:
The grasping of distinctions such as blue and yellow, long and short, male and female, friend and enemy, pleasure and pain, is called the aggregate of perception.
Moreover, if this perception is distinguished, there are six kinds, just like feeling.
The verse states:
What is different from the four is called the aggregate of formations.
The explanation states:
Apart from the four aggregates of form, feeling, perception, and consciousness, the remaining conditioned dharmas are called the aggregate of formations.
In the sutras, the Buddha BhagavÄn said:
The six groups of volition are called the aggregate of grasping formations.
This is said because of their superiority.
This group of volition is the nature of karma, and because it is the most excellent in the act of creating.
The Buddha BhagavÄn said:
Because it can create and produce conditioned dharmas, it is called the aggregate of grasping formations with activity.

If it were not so, the remaining mental factors and factors not directly associated with the mind would not be included in the aggregates, and then they could not be established as the truth of suffering and the truth of the origination of suffering. They could not be established as that which should be known and that which should be abandoned.
The Buddha BhagavÄn said:

I do not say that there is any single dharma that has not been seen or penetrated that will definitely lead to the end of suffering in the future, nor is it the same for what has not been eliminated or extinguished.
Therefore, all conditioned dharmas are included in the aggregate of formations. This meaning should be believed.
Verse:
These are the three aggregates of feeling, etc.
Explanation:
Namely, the three aggregates of feeling, perception, and formations. If established as sense bases and elements, the verse states:
Or called the sense base of mental objects and the element of mental objects, along with non-information and the unconditioned.
Explanation:
These seven kinds of dharmas are called the sense base of mental objects and the element of mental objects.
Verse:
The aggregate of consciousness is the eye, etc.
Explanation:
The eye, etc. are the sense bases. The aggregate of consciousness is the sense base of mental consciousness.
Furthermore, if this consciousness is distinguished, it becomes the aggregate of six consciousnesses, namely eye consciousness up to mental consciousness.
This aggregate of consciousness, if established as sense bases, the verse states:
Or it is said to be the sense base of mental objects.
Explanation:
If established as elements, the verse states:
Or it is said to be seven realms.
The explanation is as follows:
What are the seven?
The verse says:
Namely, the six consciousnesses and the mind faculty.
The explanation is as follows:
The eye consciousness realm up to the mental consciousness realm, and the mind realm.

Among them, the five aggregates are already said to be the twelve sense bases and eighteen realms, except for non-informative form. The form aggregate is established as ten sense bases and ten realms. The feeling, conception, and formation aggregates, and non-informative and unconditioned [dharmas], are established as the sense base of mental objects and the mental object realm.
Isn't the consciousness aggregate just the mind sense base and the six consciousness realms, as well as the mind realm?
It was previously said that only the six consciousnesses are the consciousness aggregate.
If so, apart from these six consciousnesses, what dharma is called the mind realm?
There is no separate mind realm apart from the six consciousnesses.
Nevertheless, among these consciousnesses, the verse says:
The immediately past among the six is called the mind faculty.
The explanation is as follows:
The immediately past of any one of the six consciousnesses is called the mind realm.
It is like one person first being a son and later a father, or first being a fruit and later becoming a seed.
Consciousness is also like this, first being the six consciousnesses and later becoming the mind element.
If so, there are only seventeen or twelve real elements.
Why is this?
Because the six consciousness elements and the mind element include each other.
If so, how are they established as eighteen elements?
Nevertheless, the verse says:
In order to establish the sixth basis, the elements are established as eighteen.
The explanation says:
These five kinds of consciousness elements take the five elements such as the eye as their basis.
The sixth mental consciousness element has no separate basis. In order to establish this basis, the mind element is explained.
By thus establishing the three sixes of basis, what is based on, and object, the elements are established as eighteen.
If so, the final mind of an arhat should not be the mind element, because no subsequent consciousness arises.
Is it the mind element because it immediately ceases?
This interpretation is not correct.
Why?
Because it is already in the nature of abiding mind, and the conditions are not complete, so subsequent consciousness does not arise.

Here, all conditioned [dharmas] are included by the aggregates, all contaminated [dharmas] are included by the appropriating aggregates, and all dharmas are completely included by the sense bases and elements.
It should be known that all dharmas are also briefly included.
Verse:
All dharmas are briefly included by one aggregate, one sense base, and one element.
Explanation:
Among the aggregates, by the form aggregate; among the sense bases, by the mind sense base; and among the elements, by the dharma element, all dharmas should be known to be completely included.
The meaning of inclusion taught by the TathÄgata in various places should be known in this way.
Verse:
Because of the same intrinsic nature and type.
Explanation:
This inclusion is by the same intrinsic nature and type, not by a different nature.ğŸ”½Why is it so?
Verse:
Apart from the intrinsic nature and type of other dharmas.
Explanation:
If dharmas are separated from other natures, then this nature is not associated with that. Therefore, one cannot include others by means of this nature.
For example, the eye faculty is included in the form aggregate, the eye sense base, and the eye element.
It is included in the two truths of suffering and accumulation, because they have the same nature.
It is not included in the other aggregates, etc., because their natures are not associated.
If that is so, in some places it is said that others are included by others, for example, all sentient beings are included by the four means of gathering disciples.
This inclusion is not constant, and one should know it is a provisional designation.
Why are there not twenty-one elements?
Why is this?
Because the eye, ear, and nose each have two, it should not be so.
Why is this?
The verse says:
Because of the same class, object, and consciousness, although two, they form one element.
The commentary says:ğŸ”½Here, the same class means that these two are the same as the class of the eye.
The same object means that these two have the same object as form.
The same consciousness means that these two together serve as the support for a single eye consciousness.
Therefore, although the eye faculty is two, it together forms a single realm. It should be understood that the same is true for the ear and nose.
The verse says:
If that is so, why are there two?
For the sake of adornment, two are produced.
The commentary says:
If it is really like this, how can the single realm of the eye, etc., produce two?
For the sake of adorning the support.
If it were not so, if one eye and ear were produced in one place, and one nose in one nostril, this body would be very ugly.
This is not reasonable.
If it were originally like this, and cats, weasels, pigeons, etc., were born with two eyes, ears, and noses, what adornment would they have?
If that is so, what is the purpose of producing two?
For the sake of assisting in the production of consciousness.
If a person closes one eye and opens one eye, or opens one eye and half closes one eye, the seen colors are all unclear.
For the sake of adorning consciousness and making it complete, each of the three faculties requires two places.
Having explained the aggregates, sense bases, and elements, this meaning should be explained.
What is the meaning of the aggregates, sense bases, and elements?
A verse says:
The meanings of accumulation, gate, and nature are the three names of aggregates, sense bases, and elements.
The commentary says:
All forms, whether past, future, present, internal or external, coarse or subtle, inferior or superior, far or near, are gathered together and called the form aggregate.
As this sÅ«tra says:
The meaning of aggregate as accumulation is thus established.
Here, past form is that which has already ceased due to impermanence, future is that which has not yet arisen, and present is that which has arisen but not yet ceased.
In one's own continuum it is internal, otherwise it is external, or internal and external are distinguished by the sense faculties.
Obstructed is coarse, unobstructed is subtle, or coarse and subtle are distinguished by mutual dependence.
If you say:
Coarse and subtle are not established by mutual dependence.
This is not so, because the distinction is based on difference.
If this is established as coarse in dependence on that, there is no expedient to establish it as fine in dependence on that, like a father and son.
There is defilement, which is contemptible, and no defilement, which is excellent.
The past and future are distant, and the present is near.
Up to the consciousness aggregate, it is also like this.
There is also a distinction: the five sense faculties are based on the coarse, and the mind is based on the fine.
The VaibhÄá¹£ika judges coarseness and fineness based on the ground.
There is a great virtue who says:
The objects of the five sense faculties are coarse, and what is different from this is called fine.
What is not lovable is contemptible, and what is lovable is excellent.
What is invisible is distant, and what is visible is near.
The past, etc., are manifested by their own names and do not need to be explained separately.
It should be known that feeling, etc., are also like this.
Because of following the basis, there is distance and nearness.
The meanings of coarseness and fineness are as before.
Entering means the gate through which the mind and mental factors come, or it is said to be the meaning of increase, which can increase the coming of the mind and mental factors.
Realm means different. Just as in one mountain there are many differences such as iron, copper, gold, silver, etc., therefore it is called realm.
In this way, in one basis or one continuity, there are eighteen kinds of differences, which are called the eighteen realms.
Here, different means the meaning of original nature, which refers to the homogeneous cause.
These eighteen dharmas are the homogeneous cause for the continuity of the same kind, therefore they are called different.
If that is so, then the unconditioned dharmas are not realms.
This is not so, because they are the homogeneous cause for the mind and mental factors.
Moreover, there are other masters who say:
Realm means the meaning of kind.
The kinds of dharmas are eighteen, which are called realms because of their own-nature.
If the aggregates have the meaning of accumulation, then the aggregates should be provisional, because many things are accumulated, like a heap or a person.
This is not so, because a single atom of a dharma can be called an aggregate.
If that is so, then one should not say that the aggregates have the meaning of accumulation.
Why is that?
because there is no meaning of aggregation in a single thing.
Moreover, there are other masters who say:
The meaning of skandha is that which can bear the burden of affairs.
Moreover, there are masters who say:
The meaning of skandha is that which is divided.
Why is it so?
Because there are various teachings that say one should transform the three skandhas.
This view is not in accord with the sÅ«tras.
Why is it so?
Because the sÅ«tras only say that the meaning of skandha is aggregation, as the sÅ«tra says:
Whatever form there is, whether past, future, or present... and so on, as extensively explained in the sÅ«tra.
If you say that the meaning of the aggregate of form, whether past, etc., should be known from the sÅ«tra, then all past, etc., forms would individually be called the aggregate of form.
One should not hold this view, that all forms are collected together and called the aggregate.
Because of this explanation, therefore the skandhas exist nominally like an aggregation.
In that case, for you, the form sense bases would also have to be nominally existent.
Why is it so?
because it is the gateway for the coming of many atoms.
This is not so, because each atom in the aggregate becomes a cause.
Moreover, because it cooperates with the object, the sense faculty is also not the twelve sense bases.
Therefore, in the Abhidharma, it is said:
The Abhidharma masters, if observing and speaking of the aggregates nominally, say that an atom is one element, one sense base, and one part of one aggregate.
If not observing and speaking, they say that an atom is one element, one sense base, and one aggregate.
Here, in one part, the whole is metaphorically spoken of, just as when one part of a robe is burned, the robe is said to be burned.
Moreover, how did the World-Honored One, by means of the gates of the aggregates and so forth, make three kinds of correct teachings for the assembly of disciples?
A verse says:
Because of delusion, faculties, and pleasure, the aggregates, sense bases, and elements are taught.
The commentary says:

The Abhidharma masters say it is like this: there are three kinds of delusion among sentient beings. Some sentient beings are unclear about mental factors and grasp aggregates as self. Some sentient beings are unclear about form. Some sentient beings are unclear about form and mind.
There are also three kinds of faculties, namely sharp, medium, and dull.
There are also three kinds of pleasure, namely pleasure in extensive, medium, and brief texts.
The extensive text is taught in sequence for these three people, namely the aggregates, sense bases, and elements.
What is the reason that the World-Honored Buddha places all the remaining mental factors in one aggregate of formations, but divides feeling and conceptualization into separate aggregates?
The verse says:
Because of the roots of dispute, the causes of birth and death, and the causes of sequence, among the mental factors, feeling and conceptualization are established as separate aggregates.
The explanation says:
The roots of dispute are twofold: attachment to sense objects and attachment to various views.

Feeling and conceptualization are the causes of the two [types of] disputes, because sentient beings are attached to the taste of feeling and therefore cling to sense objects, and because they cling to various views by giving rise to inverted conceptualization.
Feeling and conceptualization are the supreme causes of birth and death.
Why is this?
Because sentient beings are attached to feeling, give rise to inverted conceptualization, and revolve in birth and death.
There are also causes for establishing the sequence, which will be explained later.
Here, the sequence of causes should be understood in this way, with feeling and conceptualization being separately established as aggregates.
These causes for establishing the sequence will be explained later.
Next, why are the unconditioned [dharmas] mentioned among the elements and sense bases, but not among the aggregates?
A verse says:
In the aggregates, the unconditioned is excluded, because it is not appropriate.
The commentary says:
If the three unconditioned [dharmas] are mentioned among the five aggregates, they cannot be established to correspond with the characteristics of the aggregates.
Why is this?
Because it is not appropriate.
Why is it not appropriate?
This unconditioned dharma is not form, up to not consciousness, and cannot be said to be a sixth aggregate.ğŸ”½Why?
Because it does not have the meaning of an aggregate.
The meaning of aggregate is the meaning of heap, as previously explained.
The unconditioned has no distinctions such as past, future, and present, like form and so forth. For this reason, all that is included can be established as the unconditioned aggregate.

In order to manifest the basis of defilement, the aggregates of grasping are explained. In order to manifest the basis of both defilement and purification, the aggregates are explained. These two meanings do not exist in the unconditioned, because they are not suitable in meaning. Therefore, the unconditioned is not established within the aggregates.
Just as when a pot is broken, it is no longer a pot, so it is with the destruction of the aggregates. One cannot establish them as aggregates, say other masters.
If this is accepted, then a counter-question is established regarding the elements and sense bases.
The individual meanings of the aggregates have been explained.
Verse:
The elements are in order of coarseness, defilement, vessel, etc.
Explanation:
Form is obstructive, the coarsest of all. Among the formless realms, feeling and conceptualization are coarser in appearance.
There are worldly people who say:
My hand hurts, my foot hurts.
Conceptualization is coarser than the two, because the distinctions of male, female, etc. are easily discriminated.
Among the formless realms, consciousness is coarser in appearance, because the characteristics of desire, hatred, etc. are easily discriminated.
Among the formless realms, consciousness is the most subtle, because its own nature is difficult to discriminate.
Therefore, the coarsest is explained first.

Moreover, from beginningless birth and death, men and women mutually delight in form, out of attachment to the taste of love. This craving arises from inverted conceptualization, and this inversion arises from afflictions.
These afflictions arise from defiled mind.
Thus, the order is established according to defilement.
Moreover, the order is established according to the meanings of vessel, etc., just as a vessel, food, dishes, cook, and eater. The five aggregates of form, etc. are also like this.

Furthermore, the order is established according to the realms. The desire realm is manifested by desire for sense objects, the meditative absorptions are manifested by feeling, the three formless realms are manifested by conceptualization, and the peak of existence is manifested only by formations. These four are the abodes of consciousness, where consciousness can abide.
The order of the aggregates is established to show the order of the field and seeds.
Therefore, only five aggregates are established, neither more nor less. This is the reason for establishing the order.
Within formations, feeling and conceptualization are distinguished and established as separate aggregates, because these two are the coarsest and the causes of defilement, in order.
Feeling and conceptualization are like food and condiments, because they manifest the two realms. Therefore, they are established as separate aggregates.
In the discussion of the sense bases and elements, the order of the six sense faculties such as the eye should be explained.
Why is this?
Because the order of the sense objects and consciousnesses corresponding to them is easy to understand, therefore the six beginning with the eye are mentioned first.
A verse says:
The first five are because they have present objects.
The explanation says:
The five sense faculties such as the eye have present objects, therefore they are mentioned first.
The objects of the mental faculty are indefinite. Sometimes the mental faculty takes present objects, sometimes objects of the three times, and sometimes objects not in the three times.
Verse:
Because the four are the objects of derivative form.
Explanation:
The previous statement continues to this point. Among these five, the first four are mentioned first because derivative form is their object.
The object of the body faculty is indefinite. Sometimes the body takes the four great elements as its object, sometimes derivative form, and sometimes both together.
Verse:
The remaining faculties are mentioned in order of distance, speed, and clarity of function.
Explanation:
The remaining faculties refer to the first four faculties, which are mentioned in order.

analyzed: ç”±é æ€¥æ˜äº‹æ•…çœ¼è€³ç·£é å¢ƒï¼Œæ–¼å¾ŒäºŒå‰èªªã€‚ æ–¼å‰äºŒä¸­ï¼Œçœ¼äº‹æœ€é ï¼Œé è¦‹æ±Ÿæ²³ï¼Œä¸èè²æ•…ï¼Œæ•…çœ¼åœ¨å‰ã€‚
translated: Because the eye and ear faculties take distant objects, they are mentioned first among the latter two.ğŸ”½Among the first two, the eye faculty has the most distant function, because one can see a river from far away without hearing its sound, so the eye faculty is mentioned first.
The nose and tongue faculties have functions that are not as distant as the eye and ear faculties.
The nose and tongue faculties have functions that are not as distant as the eye and ear faculties.
The nose is mentioned first because its function is urgent. For example, before food reaches the tongue, the nose has already smelled the fragrance.
Moreover, the function of the nose is clear, as it can perceive subtle flavors and fragrances, while the tongue cannot.
The verse states:
Furthermore, according to their locations.
The explanation states:

Furthermore, among the sense faculties in the body, the eye faculty is located above, the ear faculty is next below, the nose is below the ears, the tongue is below the nose, the body faculty is mostly below the tongue, and the mind faculty is located in the space within. Therefore, their sequence is established according to their locations.
Furthermore, why are the ten sense bases all included in the form aggregate, yet only one sense base is called the form sense base?
All sense bases have the nature of dharmas, yet only one sense base is called the dharma sense base?
The verse states:
In order to distinguish the superior and to include many superior dharmas, only one sense base is called form, and only one sense base is called dharma.
The explanation states:
How is it for the sake of distinguishing?
It is wished that these ten dharmas each be known by their names, because they are established as sense faculties and sense objects, so there is no need to accumulate them.
Moreover, because of the distinctions of the eye, etc., form does not obtain the names of the eye, etc., but it is also the nature of form.
It should be known that it is the form sense-field, so this separate name is not established.
Moreover, because the form sense-field is superior within it.
Why is this?
Because it is obstructed and strong.
If touched by hands and other objects, it is immediately transformed and destroyed.
Moreover, the substance and characteristics manifest in this and that place, and it is easy to point to it because it has a shadow-like appearance.
Moreover, the world commonly knows and speaks of this sense-field as form, not knowing the other sense-fields.
In order to distinguish it, it is called the dharma sense-field, and the other sense-fields are not spoken of.
Moreover, within the dharma sense-field, many dharmas such as the aggregates are included. In order to speak of many dharmas, a general name is established.
Moreover, nirvÄá¹‡a is the most excellent dharma, included within this, not within the other sense-fields, so it is biased and receives the name of dharma.
There are also other masters who say:
Because there are twenty kinds of categories, more than other colors, and because they are the objects of the three eyes of flesh, heaven, and holy wisdom.
There are also other dharmas that have the same names as the aggregates, sense bases, and elements, which have already been explained in other sÅ«tras.
Are they all included by these three categories or not?
They are all included by these without exception.
A verse in this chapter says:
The Buddha taught the Dharma aggregates, their number is eighty thousand, they are only words and names, included in the form and formation aggregates.
The commentary says:
There are some masters who hold that the Buddha's true teaching has sound as its nature, in their view it is included in the form aggregate.
There are also some masters who hold that it has phrases as its nature, in their view it is included in the formation aggregate.
What is the quantity of these Dharma aggregates?
A verse says:
It is said to be the same quantity as the Dharma aggregates.
The commentary says:
There are some masters who say:
There is a part of Abhidharma called the Dharma Aggregate, which has a size of six thousand verses, and each Dharma Aggregate among the eighty thousand has this size.
Moreover, there are masters who say:
The teachings on each of the aggregates, etc.
The explanation is:

The correct teachings on the aggregates, sense bases, elements, dependent origination, truths, nutriments, concentrations, immeasurables, formless [absorptions], liberations, mastery-entrances, all-bases, factors of enlightenment, supernormal powers, liberations, vows, knowledges, and non-contentiousness, etc., each are called a Dharma Aggregate.
The verse states:
The Dharma Aggregates are truly determined to be the antidotes to the various practices, and are explained accordingly.
The explanation is:
The masters truly determine them in this way.
Sentient beings have eighty-four thousand types of afflictive activities, namely the distinctions of desire, anger, ignorance, pride, etc.
In order to counteract these activities, the World-Honored One correctly expounds the eighty-four thousand Dharma Aggregates.
Just as the eighty-four thousand Dharma Aggregates are included within the five aggregates, falling under the form aggregate and the formation aggregate.
Verse:

In this way, the remaining dharmas should be understood in the same way. The aggregates, sense bases, and elements, etc. are included in what has been explained before. One should carefully consider their nature.
Explanation:

If there are other aggregates, sense bases, elements, etc. explained in other sÅ«tras, they should be distinguished and included in the aggregates, sense bases, and elements explained above in this treatise.

Among them, there are five separate aggregates, namely the aggregate of morality, the aggregate of concentration, the aggregate of wisdom, the aggregate of liberation, and the aggregate of the knowledge and vision of liberation.
The aggregate of form is included in the form aggregate, the other four are included in the aggregate of mental objects.
There are also ten universal bases. Since the first eight universal bases are by nature non-greed, they are included in the dharma sense base.
If they are accompanied by their associates, they have the nature of the five aggregates, and are therefore included in the mind and dharma sense bases.
The same is true for the universal basis of non-greed.

The universal basis of space, the universal basis of consciousness, and the four formless bases of infinite space, etc. have the nature of the four aggregates, and are therefore included in the mind and dharma sense bases.
There are also five formless liberations, which are categorized as the element of dharmas because their nature is that of wisdom.
If they are considered together with their accompanying factors, they are categorized as the three elements of sound, mind, and dharmas.

There are also two formless realms, namely, the realm of neither conceptualization nor nonconceptualization. The first realm is the heaven of neither conceptualization nor nonconceptualization, which is categorized as ten elements, excluding the elements of odor and taste.
The second realm is categorized as the two elements of mind and dharmas.
Thus, in the BahudhÄtuka SÅ«tra, the Buddha spoke of sixty-two realms.
These various realms should be understood as being categorized in the eighteen elements in accordance with reason.
Among them, six realms are mentioned, namely, the earth realm, water, fire, wind, space, and consciousness.
Two of these six realms have not yet had their characteristics explained.
Should it be understood that unconditioned space is precisely the space element?
Should it be understood that all consciousness is precisely the consciousness element?
They say no.
How is it not so?
The doors, windows, and orifices of the nose, mouth, etc.
Verse:
The cavities are called the space element.
Explanation:
If cavities are mentioned, one should understand what dharma they are.
Verse:
That is said to be light and darkness.
Explanation:
Why is this?
Because no cavities apart from light and darkness can be seen.
Therefore, that which is called the space element has only light and darkness as its nature, and day and night as its time.
This space element is called the adjacent form.
That which is called obstructive form is the form that is most easily destroyed in the aggregates.
Because light and darkness are adjacent to obstructive form, it is called adjacent form.
There is also another explanation:
This is also obstructive, because others are unobstructed in it, and it is adjacent to other forms.
Verse:
The consciousness element is simply consciousness, with outflows.
Explanation:
Why is it not said to be without outflows?
Because the Buddha allows the six elements.
Verse:
The basis for birth.
Explanation:
These six elements are the basis for the mind from the first moment of conception until death. However, pure dharmas are not like this.
Thus, among these six elements, the first four are included in the element of touch, the fifth is included in the element of form, and the sixth is included in the seven elements of consciousness.
The meaning of inclusion has been explained.
Among the eighteen elements that were mentioned, how many are visible and how many are invisible?
A verse says:
Among them, one is visible, namely form.
The explanation is:
This form is easily made visible, as in saying this form, that form.
By this statement, the meaning should be understood as reaching the rest, which is not visible.
How many are obstructed and how many are unobstructed?
A verse says:
Ten are obstructed, having form.
The explanation is:
These ten elements are included in the form aggregate and are obstructed.
What is obstruction?
It is called obstruction because of mutual hindrance.
This obstruction is of three kinds:
1. obstructive obstruction, 2. obstruction by objects, 3. obstruction as condition as object.
Here, obstruction means that in its own place it obstructs the arising of another of the same kind, like hand against hand, or stone against stone.
Obstruction of objects means that the eye and other faculties are obstructed by form and other objects, as the PrajÃ±aptiÅ›Ästra says:
There is an eye that is obstructed in water but not on land, like the eyes of fish and so on.
There is an eye that is obstructed on land but not in water, for the most part like the eyes of humans and so on.
There is an eye that is obstructed in both places, like the eyes of turtles, alligators, frogs, ghosts, fishermen, and so on.
There is an eye that is unobstructed in both places, excluding the above three phrases.
There is an eye that is obstructed at night but not during the day, like the eyes of bats, owls, and so on.
There is an eye that is obstructed during the day but not at night, for the most part like the eyes of humans and so on.
There is an eye that is obstructed both during the day and night, like the eyes of dogs, jackals, horses, leopards, cats, and so on.
There is an eye that is unobstructed at both times, excluding the above three sentences.
The obstruction of objects is like this.
As for the obstruction of the condition as object, the mind and mental factors are obstructed with regard to their own objects as conditions.
What is the difference between the obstruction of objects and the obstruction of the condition as object?
The place where this dharma has the ability is called the object of this dharma, which is called the obstruction of objects.
The objects grasped by the mind and mental factors are called the obstruction of the condition as object.
How is it that this faculty is born in continuity with regard to its own object, and how is the consciousness born with regard to its object as condition, and is said to be obstructed?
Because it does not arise beyond this.
Moreover, here obstruction means reaching, that is, being born with regard to its own object. Here, it is due to obstruction.
It should be known that the ten realms have obstruction, because they obstruct each other.
If a dharma is obstructed due to the obstruction of objects, is it also obstructed due to the obstruction of hindrance?
There are four sentences.
The first sentence refers to the seven mind realms and part of the dharma realm, namely the associated mental factors.
The second phrase refers to the five sense objects.
The third phrase refers to the five sense faculties.
The fourth phrase refers to a part of the dharma realm, namely the factors not directly associated with the mind.
If a dharma is obstructed by sense objects, is it also obstructed by the condition as object?
Excluding the last two phrases, if a dharma is obstructed by the condition as object, it must be obstructed by sense objects.
There are dharmas that are obstructed by sense objects but not obstructed by the condition as object, such as the five sense faculties.
The Venerable KumÄralÄta said:
Where the mind wishes to arise, it is obstructed by others and does not arise.
One should know that this is obstruction, otherwise it is not obstruction.
Having explained obstruction,
among the eighteen realms, how many are wholesome, how many are unwholesome, and how many are indeterminate?
The verse states:
Eight are indeterminate.
What are the eight?
Among the previously mentioned ten types of obstruction, the verse states:
Excluding form and sound.
The treatise states:
The five sense faculties, smells, tastes, and tactile objects - these eight are called indeterminate because they cannot be determined as either wholesome or unwholesome.
Some say:
Because their retribution cannot be determined, they are called indeterminate.
If that is so, then it would be a counterexample for the unconditioned.
The verse states:
The remaining three natures.
The commentary explains:
The remaining ten types of elements are endowed with the natures of wholesome, unwholesome, and indeterminate.
Among them, the seven consciousness elements are wholesome when associated with non-greed, etc., unwholesome when associated with greed, etc., and indeterminate in other cases.

The dharma element is wholesome when associated with wholesome factors such as non-greed, and when producing the cessation resulting from deliberation; unwholesome when associated with unwholesome factors such as greed, and when producing; indeterminate in other cases.

The form element and sound element are wholesome or unwholesome when produced by wholesome or unwholesome minds, because they are included in bodily and verbal actions; they are indeterminate in other cases.
Having explained the good natures, etc. of the realms,
how many of the eighteen realms are associated with the desire realm?
How many are associated with the form realm and formless realm?
A verse says:
All exist in the desire realm.
The explanation says:
Associated means having, and means not separated.
In the desire realm, all eighteen are complete.
A verse says:
Fourteen in the form realm.
The explanation says:
In the form realm, they are not complete, but only fourteen.
Which fourteen?
A verse says:
Excluding smell, taste, and the nose and tongue consciousnesses.
The explanation says:
In the form realm, there are no smells and tastes, because these two are of the nature of coarse food.
Because one is born there by being free from desire for coarse food.
Because there are no such objects, the nose and tongue consciousnesses also cannot arise, because there are no objects of perception.
In that case, one should not establish the existence of the tangible realm there, because tangibility is also of the nature of coarse food.
It is true, but if touch is not of the same kind as food, it could exist there.
If so, smell and taste should also be so.
This is not so.
Why is it so?
Apart from food, there is no separate use for smell and taste like touch.
Touch has a separate use, namely, it can form the faculties, serve as a support, and form clothing, etc.
The beings there are free from desire for food, therefore smell and taste are useless, but touch is not so.
Other masters say:
Based on concentration and samÄdhi, or seeing forms and hearing sounds, there is a superior type of touch associated with pliancy that can benefit the body.
Therefore, these three are able to arise together in the place of birth in concentration, but smell and taste are not so.
If so, there should be no nose and tongue faculties there.
This is not so.
Why is it so?
These two have a use.
If separated from these two, the body would be ugly, because it lacks two faculties.
Moreover, speech is not accomplished.
If it is necessary like this, only the nose and tongue need to be supported, to adorn the body and speech, and there is no need for the two faculties of nose and tongue.
This is not so, there is no mere support that is not a faculty.
Just as the male faculty is supported there, it can be understood that it does not arise, because it is useless.
The nose and tongue are supported there, and they are useful. Therefore, if they arise there apart from the faculties, it would be reasonable.
If there are faculties that arise without use, just as in the womb, beings who are definitely going to die, without use can arise, but not without a cause can they arise.
From what cause do these faculties arise?
There is craving for the faculties.
All excellent karma, if a person is free from desire, is definitely free from desire for objects and faculties.
If that person is already free from desire for the two objects of smell and taste, the two faculties of nose and tongue should not arise there.
If the two faculties of nose and tongue arise, why would the male faculty not arise?
Because of the ugliness of the body.
If the genitals are like the sheathed organ of the elephant king, how can there be ugliness?
It is not necessarily born due to function.
How is it born?
It is born only due to causes.
Even if it is ugly, if there are causes it must be born.
Since the causes are absent, it is not born. How can it be born?
This is not correct, because it contradicts the sutra.
The sutra says:
That person is fully endowed with faculties without deficiency.
This is not correct. It is said without deficiency according to the faculties they possess. What contradiction is there?
If it were not so, the male organ would also exist in them.
They say this.
In them there are the two faculties of nose and tongue, but not smell and taste.
They give rise to craving for the six faculties through the internal sense bases, not through the external sense objects.
Craving for the male organ necessarily arises through the door of sexual touch.
Therefore this meaning is established, so there are fourteen faculties in the form realm.
Verse:
The formless realm is associated with the mental faculty, dharmas, and mind consciousness.
Explanation:

Those who have already become detached from the desire realm and are born there, the ten realms whose nature is form, and the five sense consciousnesses that use them as supports and objects, therefore in the formless realm they do not exist.
How many realms are with outflows and how many realms are without outflows?
The three realms of the mental faculty, dharmas, and consciousness, as previously explained,
Verse:
These three are with outflows and without outflows.
Explanation:
If within these three realms they are included in the truth of the path and the unconditioned, they are without outflows. Otherwise they are with outflows.
Verse:
The rest are with outflows.
Explanation:
The remaining fifteen realms are definitely only with outflows.
How many realms have initial thought and sustained thought?ğŸ”½How many realms have no initial thought but only sustained thought?
How many realms have neither initial thought nor sustained thought?
Verse:
Those with initial thought and sustained thought are definitely the five sense consciousnesses.
Explanation:
Because these five consciousnesses are always associated with initial and sustained thought, they are said to be definite. In order to distinguish them from other realms, [this is said].
The verse says:
The last three have three meanings.
The explanation says:
The mental realm, dharma realm, and mental consciousness realm are the last among the eighteen, so they are called the last.

These three categories are complete. The mental realm, mental consciousness realm, and the dharma realm associated with the mind, excluding initial and sustained thought, have initial and sustained thought in the desire realm and the first trance state, but in the intermediate trance state there is no initial thought, only sustained thought.

From the second trance state upward, up to the peak of existence, there is no initial thought or sustained thought. All dharmas not associated with the mind, and sustained thought in the intermediate trance state, are always without initial thought, only with sustained thought, because there is no second initial thought, and only because they are associated with sustained thought.
Sustained thought in the desire realm and the first trance state is not included in the three categories. What should its name be?
It is without sustained thought, only with initial thought, because there is no second sustained thought, and because it is associated with initial thought, therefore it is said to be so.
There is a stage with initial and sustained thought, where there are four kinds of dharmas:
1. With initial and sustained thought, referring to all the mental factors other than initial and sustained thought.
2. Without initial thought but with sustained thought, referring only to initial thought.
3. Without initial thought or sustained thought, referring to dharmas not associated with the mind.
4. Without sustained thought but with initial thought, referring only to sustained thought.
Verse:
The remaining sense bases are devoid of both.
Explanation:
The ten sense bases of form are called the remaining ones. These ten sense bases are always devoid of initial and sustained thought, because they are not associated with the mind.
If the group of five consciousnesses has initial and sustained thought, how can it be said to be without discrimination?
Verse:
Discrimination and recollection are absent in the two.
Explanation:
They say there are three kinds of discrimination: 1. intrinsic discrimination, 2. discrimination of manifestation, and 3. discrimination of recollection.

The five consciousnesses only have intrinsic discrimination, not the other two kinds of discrimination, so they are said to be without discrimination, like saying a horse has no feet if it only has one foot.
Among these, the intrinsic nature discrimination is precisely applied thought and sustained thought, which will be explained later in the section on mental factors.
What are the characteristics of the latter two discriminations, and what is their sequence?
A verse says:
The second is distracted cognition, all recollections are mental.
The commentary says:
This cognition is associated with mental consciousness, so it is called mental cognition. Because it is not tranquil and concentrated, it is called distracted.

This cognition is precisely the discrimination of manifestation. All recollections associated with mental consciousness, whether concentrated or distracted, are called the discrimination of recollection.
How many realms have objects as conditions?
How many realms do not have objects as conditions?
A verse says:
The seven consciousnesses have objects as conditions.
The commentary says:
The seven consciousnesses, namely eye, ear, nose, tongue, body consciousness, the mental faculty, and mental consciousness, have objects as conditions, because they can grasp objects.
A verse says:
Half of the dharma realm exists.
The commentary says:
This also has objects as conditions, because it takes mental factors as its essence.
The remaining ten form realms and part of the dharma realm that are not associated with mind should be known as having no object-support condition.
How many have grasping and how many do not have grasping?
The verse states:
Nine realms are not grasped.
The explanation states:
What are the nine?
The seven realms with object-support conditions, and half of the eighth.
The verse states:
Eight are sound.
The explanation states:
These nine are not grasped, namely the seven consciousness realms, the dharma realm, and the sound realm.
The verse states:
The remaining two.
The explanation states:
The remaining two are either with grasping or without grasping.
Among them, the eye, ear, nose, tongue, and body, if present, have grasping.
Form, smell, taste, and touch, if present and not separated from the faculties, also have grasping, the rest do not have grasping.
Like in hair, body hair, nails, teeth, feces, urine, saliva, mucus, blood, etc., and in earth, water, etc., there is grasping and non-grasping.
What is the meaning of this statement?
Mind and mental factors are included, they are the support for themselves, because they mutually follow each other in terms of benefit and harm.
It is said in the world that there is perception, this is called with attachment,
because attachment has the meaning of perception.
The remaining ones are called without attachment.ğŸ”½How many elements have the nature of the four great elements?
How many elements have the nature of the four great elements' derivatives?
The verse states:
The tangible element is of two kinds.
The explanation states:

Tangibles are the four great elements and the four great elements' derivatives. The four tangibles such as solidity are the four great elements, and the seven tangibles such as softness are the four great elements' derivatives.
Because they arise in dependence on the four great elements, they are called derivatives.
The verse states:
Nine are form and derivatives.
The explanation states:
The five sense faculties, the four objects - these nine are only derivatives.
The verse states:
And part of the element of mental objects.
The explanation states:
In the element of mental objects, unmanifested form is also said to be a derivative.
The remaining seven consciousnesses and the dharmas in the dharma realm, excluding non-information, are neither of the two.
Buddhadeva says:
The ten sense bases are only the four great elements.

This view is not correct, because in the sutras the four great elements and their characteristics of solidity, etc. are clearly explained, and because these four great elements are only tangible objects.
The characteristics of solidity, etc. are not seen by the eyes, etc., and the four sense objects such as form are not perceived by the body faculty. Therefore this view is not correct.
The Buddha, the World-Honored One, said in the sutras:
Monks!

The eye faculty is an internal sense base, dependent on the four great elements, and is the pure form derived from the four great elements. It has form, but is invisible and obstructible. The same is true for the body faculty.
Monks!
Form is an external sense base, dependent on the four great elements, and is the form derived from the four great elements. It has form, is visible, and is obstructible.
Monks!
Sound is an external sense base, dependent on the four great elements, and is the form derived from the four great elements. It has form, is invisible, and is obstructible.
The same is true for taste.
Bhiká¹£us!
Touch is an external sense base, consisting of the four great elements or derived from the four great elements, having form, no manifestation, and obstruction.
In this sÅ«tra, by including a part of touch, the four great elements are all included, and the meaning of what is not the four great elements is clearly understood.
Moreover, it is said in the sÅ«tra:
The eye is the flesh ball, in which what is hard is of the nature of what is hard.
Such sÅ«tras only say that the flesh ball is inseparable from the eye faculty, not that it is the eye faculty.
In the SÅ«tra on Entering the Womb, it is said:
Bhiká¹£us!
Entering means only the six elements.
This is said to show the fundamental basis for accomplishing sentient beings. Moreover, in this sÅ«tra, the Buddha speaks of the six kinds of contact bases.
If it were not so, then you would also have no mental factors such as feeling.
If you say that mental factors are the same as the mind, this is not so. Perception and feeling are mental factors that arise in dependence on the mind.
Therefore, this view is not correct.

Because it is said that the mind is associated with desire, therefore, as previously explained, the existence of the four great elements and the four great elements and their derivatives in the realms is established.
How many realms are composed of minute particles?
How many realms are not composed of minute particles?
A verse says:
The ten with form are composed of minute particles.
The commentary says:
The five sense faculties and the five sense objects are composed of minute particles, because they are composed of many atoms.
